item.title: Afghanistan war: Taliban back brutal rule as they strike for power
item.description: Afghanistan's ex-rulers still back brutal punishments, the BBC finds as it goes behind Taliban lines.

item.title: Afghanistan war: Do the Taliban want to conquer or compromise?
item.description: The BBC speaks to two high profile figures in its chain of command who have very different messages.

item.title: GCSES 2021: Higher results expected after exams axed
item.description: Pupils are finding out their GCSE results, as a second year of bumper grades is predicted.

item.title: UK deportation flight to Jamaica leaves with dozens reprieved
item.description: A plane to Jamaica chartered by the Home Office was carrying just seven passengers, lawyers say.

item.title: New Zealand borders to remain closed for rest of the year
item.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said her priority was vaccinating the population by the end of 2021.

item.title: Cryptocurrency heist hacker returns $260m in funds
item.description: The hacker behind the $600m Poly Network cryptocurrency heist has posted a Q&A on the blockchain.

item.title: Italy may have registered Europe's hottest temperature on record
item.description: If the registered reading is verified, it will be hottest temperature ever recorded in Europe.

item.title: Briton suspected of spying for Russia arrested in Germany
item.description: German federal prosecutors say the British man passed documents to Russian intelligence for cash.

item.title: Climate: WWF warns UK spending is lagging behind targets
item.description: The conservation group WWF says the UK government must keep its promises on climate change.

item.title: University of Leeds students offered Â£10k and free housing to defer
item.description: Some courses in the university's schools of law and business are oversubscribed.

item.title: Chingford stabbing: Two boys held after man killed in street
item.description: The 14-year-olds are in custody following the death of James Markham in east London on Monday.

item.title: Henley Royal Regatta dress code allows women to wear trousers
item.description: Henley Royal Regatta changes its rules for the Steward's Enclosure for the first time in decades.

item.title: Weight Watchers shares dive as people put diets on hold
item.description: Shares in the Oprah Winfrey-backed company drop 25% as subscriber numbers fall after lockdown.

item.title: The Papers: 'Spy sold secrets' and 'no way back for Andrew'
item.description: Thursday's papers report fears that a spy at the British embassy in Berlin sold data to Russia.

item.title: Boohoo boss: 'We're not a throwaway fashion brand'
item.description: The boss of fast fashion retailer Boohoo tells the BBC it is committed to being more sustainable.

item.title: The shopkeeper saving his island from wildfires
item.description: Spyros isn't a firefighter, but when his home was threatened with wildfires, he decided to take action.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Meet Tokyo's youngest Olympic champion
item.description: After the sport's debut in the Olympics, athletes say people are seeing it in a whole new light.

item.title: Sheffield girlfriend gives partner 'gift of life' kidney donation
item.description: Eddie Huntley has a rare disease and was on dialysis three times a week before the transplant.

item.title: Charles and Diana's wedding cake slice sells for Â£1,850
item.description: The 40-year-old slice of wedding cake was bought by a buyer from Leeds.

item.title: Afghanistan: The people fleeing the north for safety in Kabul
item.description: The Taliban has taken new territories in the north, forcing thousands out of their homes.

item.title: Wildfires: How are they linked to climate change?
item.description: A series of major wildfires across the world has hit the headlines - how do they compare to previous years?

item.title: National anthem: Should Wales' teams sing God Save the Queen?
item.description: Hen Wlad Fy Nhadau has been sung before Wales rugby internationals for 116 years.

item.title: Mapping the advance of the Taliban in Afghanistan
item.description: Maps of Afghanistan show who controls districts in fighting between the government and Taliban forces.

item.title: The Orielles: How the band turned their album into a film score
item.description: The band on surreal gigs at cricket grounds and the "happenings" that inspired their new project.

item.title: Fenty Beauty: How make-up helped Rihanna become a billionaire
item.description: Rihanna makes more money from her make-up than from her music and acting work.

item.title: The labels encouraging Chileans to buy healthier food
item.description: Chile's government introduced food labelling five years ago to drive down its high obesity rate.

item.title: Uefa Super Cup: Chelsea defeat Villarreal on penalties in Belfast to lift trophy for second time
item.description: Chelsea beat Villarreal 6-5 in a penalty shootout to lift the Uefa Super Cup for a second time after a draining 120 minutes of action ends 1-1 in Belfast.

item.title: England's Broad out of India series - Anderson a doubt for second Test
item.description: Stuart Broad will miss the remainder of England's series against India because of a calf tear and James Anderson is a doubt for the second Test.

item.title: Brave's men storm to top of table and eliminate Fire
item.description: Southern Brave cruise to a comfortable win over Welsh Fire which takes them to the top of the table.

item.title: Kepa goes from shootout villain to Super Cup hero
item.description: Kepa Arrizabalaga's time at Chelsea has been defined by an incident involving a substitution with penalties looming - and now another, but in much happier circumstances.

item.title: Konta beats third seed Svitolina at Canadian Open
item.description: British number one Johanna Konta fights back from a set down to defeat third seed Elina Svitolina and reach the Canadian Open third round.

item.title: The Hundred: Leus du Plooy, Smriti Mandhana & David Lloyd star as Southern Brave take on Welsh Fire
item.description: Watch the best of Wednesday's Hundred action as Southern Brave's women and men both secure big wins against Welsh Fire at the Ageas Bowl.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Fertility and miscarriage claims fact-checked
item.description: Posts claiming Covid vaccines cause miscarriages are not supported by scientific evidence.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England, Scotland and Wales but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: The working from home advice in England is set to change on 19 July.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: The government has updated its red, amber and green lists of countries.

item.title: Malta: The teenagers pulled from the sea and accused of terrorism
item.description: How three teenagers rescued from the Mediterranean Sea ended up in Malta accused of terrorism.

item.title: âIf only Iâd found out earlier I had pelvic congestion syndromeâ
item.description: Sophie Robehmed suffered from back and stomach pains for years before being diagnosed with PCS.

item.title: From Afghan interpreter to US homeless - the long road to the American dream
item.description: Thousands of Afghan interpreters have waited years to flee to the US. Arriving is a different story.

item.title: Riots 10 years on: The five summer nights when London burned
item.description: In August 2011 a man was shot dead by police in London, triggering the worst civil unrest in decades.
